update.description:
I rewrote rendering::FPSViewController to pan the camera based on WASD input. The viewpoint rotates when the user holds left click and moves the mouse around.

To use it, insert the following line into your favorite plugin (preferably the constructor of a GUI Plugin):

```
#!c++

  gui::get_active_camera()->SetViewController(
                          rendering::FPSViewController::GetTypeString());
```

Further work on this front: configurable key bindings, configurable camera speed, and an option to set the viewpoint in the GUI. ~~In the meantime, I hope to incorporate this into HAPTIX.~~ no longer needed for Haptix, so not a priority for 10/27/14 sprint
update.title: (re-)Implemented FPSViewController

content.raw: I believe that plugins are usually exempt from PIMPL, so I think the Haptix GUIPlugin is ok without it.
content.html: I believe that plugins are usually exempt from PIMPL, so I think the Haptix GUIPlugin is ok without it.

content.raw: Nate's modifications add an option for changing the ViewController in the drop-down GUI menu.
content.html: Nate's modifications add an option for changing the ViewController in the drop-down GUI menu.

content.raw:
Thanks for the tips. It's good to have clarification about which parts of Gazebo I should internalize as good code practices and which parts we are slowly revising.

My thought in adding a velocity attribute to Camera was in case we implement more ViewControllers in the future (or other developers implement ViewControllers) that set the velocity of the camera. It also seemed like a natural choice to add a velocity component to Camera, since it has functions for change the rotation and translation of the camera. However, it sounds like I misinterpreted the intended functionality of Camera vs. ViewController.

... the note about PIMPL would have been good to know before I started working on the Haptix GUIPlugin, but we can discuss that in another thread.
content.html:
Thanks for the tips. It's good to have clarification about which parts of Gazebo I should internalize as good code practices and which parts we are slowly revising.

My thought in adding a velocity attribute to Camera was in case we implement more ViewControllers in the future (or other developers implement ViewControllers) that set the velocity of the camera. It also seemed like a natural choice to add a velocity component to Camera, since it has functions for change the rotation and translation of the camera. However, it sounds like I misinterpreted the intended functionality of Camera vs. ViewController.

... the note about PIMPL would have been good to know before I started working on the Haptix GUIPlugin, but we can discuss that in another thread.

content.raw:
I've made a number of modifications in the fps_control_nate. Please take a look, and merge if acceptable.

A couple of notes:

1. We are slowly PIMPL-izing our classes. The is also known as using an opaque pointer. See [here](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opaque_pointer#C.2B.2B). If you run across a class, such as Camera, that has a private data pointer, then you should add new class attributes to that private class. If you are creating a new class, please follow the PIMPL idiom (as with everything, there can be exceptions to this rule).

1. Use the `this` pointer religiously. It's not required by the c++ spec, but it's part of our style that helps to increase code readability and clarity. 

1. Try to keep functionality compartmentalized. For example, in your implementation of FPS view control the camera motion is partly controlled in the Camera class via `velocity` and partly in the FPSViewController class. In this case it is better to keep all camera control in the FPSViewController class.
content.html:
I've made a number of modifications in the fps_control_nate. Please take a look, and merge if acceptable.

A couple of notes:

  1. We are slowly PIMPL-izing our classes. The is also known as using an opaque pointer. See here. If you run across a class, such as Camera, that has a private data pointer, then you should add new class attributes to that private class. If you are creating a new class, please follow the PIMPL idiom (as with everything, there can be exceptions to this rule).

  2. Use the this pointer religiously. It's not required by the c++ spec, but it's part of our style that helps to increase code readability and clarity.

  3. Try to keep functionality compartmentalized. For example, in your implementation of FPS view control the camera motion is partly controlled in the Camera class via velocity and partly in the FPSViewController class. In this case it is better to keep all camera control in the FPSViewController class.

content.raw: mm releasing `s` causes the gui to switch to scale mode.
content.html: mm releasing s causes the gui to switch to scale mode.

content.raw:
It can also be enabled in a world file by changing the `<view_controller>` tag from `orbit` to `fps` (the following was taken from 
[test/worlds/transparency.world](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/6b22d2744e0c2f3a77e19b6ed8e9ef9b6b677fd0/test/worlds/transparency.world?at=default#cl-78)):
~~~
<gui fullscreen='0'>
  <camera name='user_camera'>
    <pose>5.0 -10.0 1.5  0.0 0.0 1.57079</pose>
    <view_controller>fps</view_controller>
  </camera>
</gui>
~~~
Speaking of which, perhaps we can add an example world that uses the fps view controller?
content.html:
It can also be enabled in a world file by changing the <view_controller> tag from orbit to fps (the following was taken from test/worlds/transparency.world):

<gui fullscreen='0'>
  <camera name='user_camera'>
    <pose>5.0 -10.0 1.5  0.0 0.0 1.57079</pose>
    <view_controller>fps</view_controller>
  </camera>
</gui>

Speaking of which, perhaps we can add an example world that uses the fps view controller?
